elements.content: A postsynthetic modification (PSM) scheme for metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) has been developed using a tetrazine-based “Click” reaction. It was found that the efficacy of this modification procedure was dependent on the MOF topology and, in the case of an isoreticular MOF (IRMOF) system, required the formation of a mixed-ligand IRMOF with a suitable ratio of 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate (BDC) and an olefin-tagged BDC derivative. On the basis of the versatile use of tetrazine “Click” chemistry in bioconjugate chemistry, we expect that this scheme will prove to be a useful reaction for preparing functionalized materials, including MOFs.
elements.clean_text: A postsynthetic modification (PSM) scheme for metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) has been developed using a tetrazine-based "Click" reaction. It was found that the efficacy of this modification procedure was dependent on the MOF topology and, in the case of an isoreticular MOF (IRMOF) system, required the formation of a mixed-ligand IRMOF with a suitable ratio of 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate (BDC) and an olefin-tagged BDC derivative. On the basis of the versatile use of tetrazine "Click" chemistry in bioconjugate chemistry, we expect that this scheme will prove to be a useful reaction for preparing functionalized materials, including MOFs.

elements.content: The inverse-electron-demand Diels−Alder “Click” reaction with tetrazines was successfully used for the postsynthetic modification of two metal−organic framework (MOF) topologies. Crowding was found to limit the reactivity of tetrazines with fully “tagged” isoreticular MOFs (IRMOFs), which could be overcome by the use of a mixed-ligand IRMOF.
elements.clean_text: The inverse-electron-demand Diels-Alder "Click" reaction with tetrazines was successfully used for the postsynthetic modification of two metal-organic framework (MOF) topologies. Crowding was found to limit the reactivity of tetrazines with fully "tagged" isoreticular MOFs (IRMOFs), which could be overcome by the use of a mixed-ligand IRMOF.

elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) are crystalline, porous solids constructed from inorganic metal-ion clusters and polytopic organic linkers. Owing to their high surface areas, uniform pores, and chemical tunability, MOFs are of increasing interest for a variety of applications including gas adsorption, catalysis, and biomedicine, among others. Moreover, functionalization of MOFs is important in expanding the chemical diversity and potential applications of MOFs. Postsynthetic modification (PSM) has emerged as an important late-stage approach to functionalizing MOFs. Generally, PSM requires that the organic ligand of the MOF contain a chemical “tag” or “handle”, such as an amine, aldehyde, or alkyne, to provide a site for coupling to a soluble reagent. Among the chemical handles reported, MOFs bearing amine groups have been the most widely employed and investigated. In order for PSM to achieve its full potential, it is essential that new chemical handles and new PSM reactions be developed for MOF functionalization.
elements.clean_text: Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are crystalline, porous solids constructed from inorganic metal-ion clusters and polytopic organic linkers. Owing to their high surface areas, uniform pores, and chemical tunability, MOFs are of increasing interest for a variety of applications including gas adsorption, catalysis, and biomedicine, among others. Moreover, functionalization of MOFs is important in expanding the chemical diversity and potential applications of MOFs. Postsynthetic modification (PSM) has emerged as an important late-stage approach to functionalizing MOFs. Generally, PSM requires that the organic ligand of the MOF contain a chemical "tag" or "handle", such as an amine, aldehyde, or alkyne, to provide a site for coupling to a soluble reagent. Among the chemical handles reported, MOFs bearing amine groups have been the most widely employed and investigated. In order for PSM to achieve its full potential, it is essential that new chemical handles and new PSM reactions be developed for MOF functionalization.

elements.content: Both alkyne and azide handles have been introduced into MOFs for use in “Click” chemistry for PSM. This [3 + 2] cycloaddition generally requires a copper(I) catalyst to accelerate the reaction, which has the potential to be trapped in the pores of the MOF. Herein, we demonstrate that a “Click” Diels–Alder [4 + 2] cycloaddition reaction using tetrazines as the only reagent can be performed on MOFs in a PSM fashion. As electron-deficient dienes, 1,2,4,5-tetrazines (also called s-tetrazines) and their derivatives rapidly react with electron-rich alkenes or alkynes by an inverse-electron-demand Diels–Alder reaction to yield dihydropyridazines or pyridazines (Scheme S1 in the , SI). These reactions are facile and reliable, can be used to prepare various substituted pyridazines, fused heterocycles, and have been employed in the labeling of biomolecules and as key steps in the total synthesis of complex organic molecules. Recently, the use of this reaction was described for the functionalization of polymers. In addition, these Click reactions do not require a catalyst or other coreagents and liberate dinitrogen as the only byproduct, making this transformation very attractive for use in the PSM of MOFs.
elements.clean_text: Both alkyne and azide handles have been introduced into MOFs for use in "Click" chemistry for PSM. This [3 + 2] cycloaddition generally requires a copper(I) catalyst to accelerate the reaction, which has the potential to be trapped in the pores of the MOF. Herein, we demonstrate that a "Click" Diels-Alder [4 + 2] cycloaddition reaction using tetrazines as the only reagent can be performed on MOFs in a PSM fashion. As electron-deficient dienes, 1,2,4,5-tetrazines (also called s-tetrazines) and their derivatives rapidly react with electron-rich alkenes or alkynes by an inverse-electron-demand Diels-Alder reaction to yield dihydropyridazines or pyridazines (Scheme S1 in the , SI). These reactions are facile and reliable, can be used to prepare various substituted pyridazines, fused heterocycles, and have been employed in the labeling of biomolecules and as key steps in the total synthesis of complex organic molecules. Recently, the use of this reaction was described for the functionalization of polymers. In addition, these Click reactions do not require a catalyst or other coreagents and liberate dinitrogen as the only byproduct, making this transformation very attractive for use in the PSM of MOFs.

elements.content: A stepwise, “tandem” approach was adopted for the PSM of MOFs by tetrazine reagents (Scheme ). UMCM-1-NH2 (UMCM = University of Michigan Crystalline Material) was selected because of its large pore size and previous successes with PSM reactions. UMCM-1-NH2 was quantitatively modified with pentenoic anhydride to produce a functionalized MOF (UMCM-1-AMPent) with an olefin group appended to the 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate ligands [BDC; as confirmed by 1H NMR spectroscopy upon digestion of the material in DCl/D2O/dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO)-d 6; Figure ]. The olefin-bearing UMCM-1-AMPent was then treated with dimethyl-1,2,4,5-tetrazine-3,6-dicarboxylate (TDC) at room temperature in CHCl3 for 24 h. Digestion of the resulting material in DCl/D2O/DMSO-d 6 followed by 1H NMR analysis confirmed the formation of the expected Diels–Alder cycloaddition product (dihydropyridazine) with complete consumption of alkene (Figure ). The new MOF, UMCM-1-AMPent-TDC, remained highly crystalline, stable, and microporous, as evidenced by single-crystal X-ray diffraction (XRD; Table S1 and Figure S1 in the ), powder XRD (PXRD), thermal gravimetric analysis (Figure S2 in the ), and gas sorption analysis. The Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface area of UMCM-1-AMPent-TDC was determined to be ∼2800 m2/g (based on two independent experiments, Figure ), which is lower than that of the parent UMCM-1-NH2 but not unexpected based on the introduction of bulky substituents into the pores.
elements.clean_text: A stepwise, "tandem" approach was adopted for the PSM of MOFs by tetrazine reagents (Scheme ). UMCM-1-NH2 (UMCM = University of Michigan Crystalline Material) was selected because of its large pore size and previous successes with PSM reactions. UMCM-1-NH2 was quantitatively modified with pentenoic anhydride to produce a functionalized MOF (UMCM-1-AMPent) with an olefin group appended to the 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate ligands [BDC; as confirmed by 1H NMR spectroscopy upon digestion of the material in DCl/D2O/dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO)-d 6; Figure ]. The olefin-bearing UMCM-1-AMPent was then treated with dimethyl-1,2,4,5-tetrazine-3,6-dicarboxylate (TDC) at room temperature in CHCl3 for 24 h. Digestion of the resulting material in DCl/D2O/DMSO-d 6 followed by 1H NMR analysis confirmed the formation of the expected Diels-Alder cycloaddition product (dihydropyridazine) with complete consumption of alkene (Figure ). The new MOF, UMCM-1-AMPent-TDC, remained highly crystalline, stable, and microporous, as evidenced by single-crystal X-ray diffraction (XRD; Table S1 and Figure S1 in the ), powder XRD (PXRD), thermal gravimetric analysis (Figure S2 in the ), and gas sorption analysis. The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area of UMCM-1-AMPent-TDC was determined to be ~2800 m2/g (based on two independent experiments, Figure ), which is lower than that of the parent UMCM-1-NH2 but not unexpected based on the introduction of bulky substituents into the pores.

elements.clean_text: 1  Tandem Approach for PSM of UMCM-1-NH2 (top) and Mixed IRMOFs (bottom) with a Tetrazine in an Inverse-Electron-Demand Diels-Alder Reaction

elements.content: 1H NMR spectra (top, samples digested in DCl/D2O/DMSO-d 6), PXRD patterns (middle), and dinitrogen isotherms (bottom) of UMCM-1-NH2 (black), UMCM-1-AMPent (blue), and UMCM-1-AMPent-TDC (red). The BET surface areas for the MOFs were ∼4000, 3600, and 2800 m2/g, respectively.
elements.clean_text: 1   1H NMR spectra (top, samples digested in DCl/D2O/DMSO-d 6), PXRD patterns (middle), and dinitrogen isotherms (bottom) of UMCM-1-NH2 (black), UMCM-1-AMPent (blue), and UMCM-1-AMPent-TDC (red). The BET surface areas for the MOFs were ~4000, 3600, and 2800 m2/g, respectively.

elements.content: Other olefin groups were also found to be suitable for the tetrazine PSM reaction. Another tagged MOF, UMCM-1-URAl, which contains an olefin group attached to the BDC ligand via a urea linkage, was prepared (see the for details). UMCM-1-URAl was obtained by treating UMCM-1-NH2 with allyl isocyanate (Scheme S2 in the ), giving the olefin-bearing material in essentially complete conversion. UMCM-1-URAl was then treated with TDC, which underwent cycloaddition, quantitatively converting the olefin groups to the dihydropyridazine product (UMCM-1-URAl-TDC), as confirmed by 1H NMR and electrospray ionization mass spectrometry (ESI-MS) analysis (Figure S3 in the ). PXRD data showed that UMCM-1-URAl-TDC was highly crystalline as well (Figure S4 in the ). In order to further generalize these findings for a different MOF topology, IRMOF-3 (IRMOF = isoreticular metal–organic framework) was prepared according to literature procedures and quantitatively modified with pentenoic anhydride. However, attempts to modify IRMOF-3-AMPent with TDC were incomplete, showing no more than ca. 20% conversion, even under reaction conditions utilizing elevated temperatures, longer reaction times, and excess TDC (Figure S5 in the ).
elements.clean_text: Other olefin groups were also found to be suitable for the tetrazine PSM reaction. Another tagged MOF, UMCM-1-URAl, which contains an olefin group attached to the BDC ligand via a urea linkage, was prepared (see the  for details). UMCM-1-URAl was obtained by treating UMCM-1-NH2 with allyl isocyanate (Scheme S2 in the ), giving the olefin-bearing material in essentially complete conversion. UMCM-1-URAl was then treated with TDC, which underwent cycloaddition, quantitatively converting the olefin groups to the dihydropyridazine product (UMCM-1-URAl-TDC), as confirmed by 1H NMR and electrospray ionization mass spectrometry (ESI-MS) analysis (Figure S3 in the ). PXRD data showed that UMCM-1-URAl-TDC was highly crystalline as well (Figure S4 in the ). In order to further generalize these findings for a different MOF topology, IRMOF-3 (IRMOF = isoreticular metal-organic framework) was prepared according to literature procedures and quantitatively modified with pentenoic anhydride. However, attempts to modify IRMOF-3-AMPent with TDC were incomplete, showing no more than ca. 20% conversion, even under reaction conditions utilizing elevated temperatures, longer reaction times, and excess TDC (Figure S5 in the ).

elements.content: The contrast between the facile reactivity of the UMCM system compared to the IRMOF suggested to us that the smaller pore size and steric crowding of the olefin groups in the latter might be hindering the progress of the PSM reaction with TDC. To test this hypothesis, a series of mixed-ligand MOFs, comprised of both BDC and NH2–BDC in different ratios, were prepared (Table S2 in the ). As found in previous reports of mixed MOFs, the mole fraction of NH2–BDC in the IRMOF (obtained by 1H NMR spectra of the digested products in DCl/D2O/DMSO-d 6; Figure S6 in the ) shows a linear relationship with the ratio of BDC and NH2–BDC in the solvothermal reaction mixture. In this manner, IRMOFs were prepared containing from 44 to 100% NH2–BDC in the framework (Table S2 in the ). Treating any of the mixed-ligand IRMOFs with pentenoic anhydride resulted in a quantitative conversion to the mixed materials containing BDC and olefin-bearing BDC ligands [i.e., IRMOF-3-(AMPent) n , where n = mole fraction of the functionalized ligand; ]. As expected, the BET surface areas of IRMOF-3-(AMPent) n materials show a linear increase as the proportion of modified ligand decreases (i.e., as n gets smaller; Table S3 in the ). This finding is consistent with earlier studies on MOFs that had undergone different degrees of PSM. The IRMOF-3-(AMPent) n materials were then further modified with TDC at 55 °C for 48 h. As shown in the 1H NMR spectra of the digested products in Figure , when the mole fraction of olefin-functionalized BDC (i.e., AMPent-BDC) was ≤0.67, complete conversion to the cycloaddition product was obtained. The 1H NMR data are supported by ESI-MS(−) analysis, which shows only product ions from the dihydropyridazine-containing BDC ligand (Figure S8 in the ). PXRD (Figure S9 in the ) and single-crystal XRD indicate that the final IRMOF-3-AMPent-TDC is highly crystalline (Figure S10 in the ).
elements.clean_text: The contrast between the facile reactivity of the UMCM system compared to the IRMOF suggested to us that the smaller pore size and steric crowding of the olefin groups in the latter might be hindering the progress of the PSM reaction with TDC. To test this hypothesis, a series of mixed-ligand MOFs, comprised of both BDC and NH2-BDC in different ratios, were prepared (Table S2 in the ). As found in previous reports of mixed MOFs, the mole fraction of NH2-BDC in the IRMOF (obtained by 1H NMR spectra of the digested products in DCl/D2O/DMSO-d 6; Figure S6 in the ) shows a linear relationship with the ratio of BDC and NH2-BDC in the solvothermal reaction mixture. In this manner, IRMOFs were prepared containing from 44 to 100% NH2-BDC in the framework (Table S2 in the ). Treating any of the mixed-ligand IRMOFs with pentenoic anhydride resulted in a quantitative conversion to the mixed materials containing BDC and olefin-bearing BDC ligands [i.e., IRMOF-3-(AMPent) n , where n = mole fraction of the functionalized ligand; ]. As expected, the BET surface areas of IRMOF-3-(AMPent) n  materials show a linear increase as the proportion of modified ligand decreases (i.e., as n gets smaller; Table S3 in the ). This finding is consistent with earlier studies on MOFs that had undergone different degrees of PSM. The IRMOF-3-(AMPent) n  materials were then further modified with TDC at 55 °C for 48 h. As shown in the 1H NMR spectra of the digested products in Figure , when the mole fraction of olefin-functionalized BDC (i.e., AMPent-BDC) was ≤0.67, complete conversion to the cycloaddition product was obtained. The 1H NMR data are supported by ESI-MS(-) analysis, which shows only product ions from the dihydropyridazine-containing BDC ligand (Figure S8 in the ). PXRD (Figure S9 in the ) and single-crystal XRD indicate that the final IRMOF-3-AMPent-TDC is highly crystalline (Figure S10 in the ).

elements.content: 1H NMR spectra of IRMOF-3-(AMPent-TDC) n samples (digested in DCl/D2O/DMSO-d 6). From top to bottom are shown IRMOF-3-(AMPent-TDC)0.44, -(AMPent-TDC)0.52, -(AMPent-TDC)0.67, -(AMPent-TDC)0.75, -(AMPent-TDC)0.85, and -(AMPent-TDC)1, respectively. Note the complete loss of the starting material olefin resonances at ∼5 ppm in samples with ≤67% functionalized BDC ligand.
elements.clean_text: 2   1H NMR spectra of IRMOF-3-(AMPent-TDC) n  samples (digested in DCl/D2O/DMSO-d 6). From top to bottom are shown IRMOF-3-(AMPent-TDC)0.44, -(AMPent-TDC)0.52, -(AMPent-TDC)0.67, -(AMPent-TDC)0.75, -(AMPent-TDC)0.85, and -(AMPent-TDC)1, respectively. Note the complete loss of the starting material olefin resonances at ~5 ppm in samples with ≤67% functionalized BDC ligand.

elements.content: In conclusion, we successfully utilized an inverse-electron-demand Diels–Alder reaction for the PSM of two different MOF frameworks. It was discovered that for an IRMOF material modulating the ratio of tagged linker was essential for obtaining efficient functionalization, which highlights the importance of utilizing mixed-ligand MOFs. The applicability of this reaction should allow for PSM with MOFs bearing various dienophiles or heterodienophiles, such as electron-rich olefins, acetylenes, enol ethers, enamines, benzynes, and others. The ability to prepare diversely functionalized tetrazines should allow for the introduction of unprecedented, new functionality into MOFs. Indeed, our preliminary efforts demonstrate that different tetrazines and different olefin-tagged MOFs can undergo this chemistry, the results of which will be reported in due course.
elements.clean_text: In conclusion, we successfully utilized an inverse-electron-demand Diels-Alder reaction for the PSM of two different MOF frameworks. It was discovered that for an IRMOF material modulating the ratio of tagged linker was essential for obtaining efficient functionalization, which highlights the importance of utilizing mixed-ligand MOFs. The applicability of this reaction should allow for PSM with MOFs bearing various dienophiles or heterodienophiles, such as electron-rich olefins, acetylenes, enol ethers, enamines, benzynes, and others. The ability to prepare diversely functionalized tetrazines should allow for the introduction of unprecedented, new functionality into MOFs. Indeed, our preliminary efforts demonstrate that different tetrazines and different olefin-tagged MOFs can undergo this chemistry, the results of which will be reported in due course.

metadata.title: Tandem Postsynthetic Modification of Metal–Organic Frameworks Using an Inverse-Electron-Demand Diels–Alder Reaction
